steps.title: Barn
steps.content: Barn The entire arena where you play ice hockey . Related: A very close, high-scoring game is a barn burner . Context: Might be a holdover from when "indoor" hockey rinks were built in literal barns. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Flood
steps.content: Flood When the Zamboni has just finished resurfacing the ice after a game, there's usually a lot of water left on the surface. The players have to wait through the flood until the water on the ice dries up so they can play.

steps.title: Hashmarks
steps.content: Hashmarks These lines intersect the 2 big circles in front of both nets and mark where players line up for face-offs.

steps.title: House
steps.content: House The area in front of the net

steps.title: Pipes
steps.content: Pipes The goal posts

steps.title: The 6x4
steps.content: The 6x4 The goal

steps.title: Slot
steps.content: Slot The area in between the two circles right in front of the net. Most goals are scored from the slot .

steps.title: Top shelf
steps.content: Top shelf The area of the net just below the crossbar Related: People talking about a top shelf goal might say " Where does mama keep the cookies? " (The answer is "the top shelf").

steps.title: Top cheese/top cheddar
steps.content: Top cheese/top cheddar The top 2 corners of the goal

steps.title: Basket
steps.content: Basket The goal, but more specifically, the net

steps.title: Breezers
steps.content: Breezers This slang term for hockey pants is primarily used in Minnesota and Wisconsin. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Biscuit
steps.content: Biscuit Hockey puck. Other slang terms for puck include rubber and frozen rubber . Related: If the puck hits the back of the net on a goal, that's a biscuit in the basket

steps.title: Bucket/brain bucket
steps.content: Bucket/brain bucket Helmet

steps.title: Cage
steps.content: Cage A full wire visor, typically worn to avoid getting teeth knocked out Context: Youth players are typically required to wear a cage of some sort as part of their protective gear. While cages aren't generally required for adults, some do wear them. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Fishbowl
steps.content: Fishbowl A full transparent visor with a transparent cage underneath, typically worn to protect your face or avoid getting teeth knocked out.

steps.title: Lumber
steps.content: Lumber Hockey stick

steps.title: Pillows
steps.content: Pillows The large pads goalies wear on their legs

steps.title: Sweater
steps.content: Sweater A hockey jersey Context: Historically, ice hockey was played outdoors. Players actually played in very warm wool sweaters so they wouldn't freeze during the game. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Beautician
steps.content: Beautician A player who is smooth and charismatic both on and off the ice.

steps.title: Bender
steps.content: Bender A player who is relatively new and hasn't yet developed good ankle strength, causing their ankles to bend outward when they're on the ice. More often used by players to insult other players. [5] X Research source Related: A newbie might also be referred to as an ankle burner for the way their ankles bend when they skate

steps.title: Chiclets
steps.content: Chiclets Teeth Context: Hockey is a rough, full-contact sport, and pucks and sticks are hard. Hockey players tend to lose teeth playing, and broken teeth tend to look like Chiclets chewing gum when you see them laying on the ice. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Chippy
steps.content: Chippy When players get irritated and are snapping at one another. Can also be used to describe a game that's full of cheap shots that the refs aren't calling. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Chirp
steps.content: Chirp To trash-talk. There are many common chirps in hockey, typically related to the player's slowness or inability to play.

steps.title: Duster/dusty
steps.content: Duster/dusty A player who doesn't play very often; a bench-warmer

steps.title: Flamingo
steps.content: Flamingo A player who lifts a leg rather than attempting to block a shot that comes by them.

steps.title: Flow
steps.content: Flow Long, luxuriant hair that flows out of the back and sides of a player's helmet. Related: Hair that's a little long but not quite long enough to qualify as flow is known as lettuce . If it's even shorter than that, it's considered salad .

steps.title: Goon
steps.content: Goon A player who has little purpose on the ice other than stirring up trouble. A goon frequently starts fights and delivers illegal hits.

steps.title: Grinder
steps.content: Grinder A player who has great work ethic and is a good checker. They're a strong defensive player but likely haven't scored many goals.

steps.title: Grocery stick
steps.content: Grocery stick A player who is so bad they sit on the bench for basically the entire game, separating the offense from the defense the way the stick on the grocery store conveyor belt separates the groceries of different shoppers.

steps.title: Hoser
steps.content: Hoser Now, ice rinks use Zambonis to resurface the ice after a game. But pre-Zamboni, the losing team had to do it—hence hoser , an insult that essentially means loser . Context: This origin is unsubstantiated, with other origin stories also proposed. However, the word is indisputably Canadian. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Lip sweater
steps.content: Lip sweater A moustache

steps.title: Mucker
steps.content: Mucker A mucker is sort of a combination between a goon and a grinder . They work hard and they fight hard.

steps.title: Pigeon
steps.content: Pigeon A less-experienced player who hangs around near the goal and waits for teammates to feed them a pass that they can easily convert into a goal.

steps.title: Playmaker
steps.content: Playmaker A player who has excellent puck handling and passing ability but doesn't score very often.

steps.title: Plumber
steps.content: Plumber A hard-working player who checks a lot and opens up the ice for plays, even if they're not really at the heart of the action.

steps.title: Puck bunny
steps.content: Puck bunny A young woman who is interested in dating a hockey player, but typically doesn't have any extensive knowledge or understanding of the game.

steps.title: Pylon
steps.content: Pylon A player who is a slow skater and is easy to maneuver around.

steps.title: Rink rat
steps.content: Rink rat A person who either works at the rink or just loves being there and is hanging out there all the time.

steps.title: Rocket
steps.content: Rocket A physically attractive person in the stands at a game.

steps.title: Soft hands
steps.content: Soft hands A player that makes smooth, slick moves with their hands and stick and can easily confuse other players. Synonyms: silky mitts, saucy paws

steps.title: The Show
steps.content: The Show Refers to professional ice hockey—primarily the NHL, but really any professional ice hockey league. Related: Hockey fans might also refer to the NHL as Chel .

steps.title: Stripes
steps.content: Stripes Referees or linesmen Synonyms: liney, zebras

steps.title: Wheels
steps.content: Wheels A player who happens to be a particularly fast skater

steps.title: Apple
steps.content: Apple An assist, when one player passes to another who's in position to score.

steps.title: Alley-oop
steps.content: Alley-oop A high pass lofted to a faraway player or a faraway position on the ice that a player is streaking toward.

steps.title: Cherry picking
steps.content: Cherry picking When a player stays back rather than defending and waits for a pass so they can make a breakaway.

steps.title: Coughing up the puck
steps.content: Coughing up the puck When a player loses possession.

steps.title: Coast to coast
steps.content: Coast to coast When a player carries the puck from one end of the ice all the way to the other.

steps.title: Dangle
steps.content: Dangle When a player keeps the puck on their stick and smoothly takes the puck through numerous opponents. Context: Likely just stretching the definition of the existing word, it implies that this smooth, skilled player is holding the puck out on their stick as bait to induce the opposing players to come after them. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Deke
steps.content: Deke A move players make with their head or body that fakes their opponent out of position. Context: When interviewed in 1960 about his fake-out skills, NHLer Dickie Moore stated that he called them dekes , which was short for decoys . [10] X Research source

steps.title: Dirty
steps.content: Dirty A really good deke or move around another player that shows some finesse and skill is described as dirty . Related: Along the same theme, a good play might also be described as filthy .

steps.title: Draw
steps.content: Draw A face-off between two players

steps.title: Dump and chase
steps.content: Dump and chase A style of play where the team shoots the puck all the way to the other end of the ice, then chases after it to try to score. Related: The player who shoots the puck this way without icing it might say they were taking a dump .

steps.title: Fan
steps.content: Fan When a player misses a pass or a shot.

steps.title: Freezing the puck
steps.content: Freezing the puck When a player holds the puck against the boards or a goalie keeps the puck to force a stoppage of play.

steps.title: Grenade
steps.content: Grenade A bad pass that causes the puck to flip and roll rather than gliding smoothly across the ice.

steps.title: Gong show
steps.content: Gong show A game that's out of control and unpredictable, usually with a lot of big hits or fights or some controversial calls. Often also features a really lopsided score.

steps.title: Hotdogging
steps.content: Hotdogging When a player is making a lot of fancy moves and showing off, usually around a less-skilled player they're trying to intimidate.

steps.title: Kronwalled
steps.content: Kronwalled When a defensive player comes out with a huge hit against an opposing player. Context: The move is named for NHL player Niklas Kronwall and his legendary, massive checks.

steps.title: Man on
steps.content: Man on Players use this phrase to tell a teammate when there's an opponent closing in on them. If there's more than one, they might say two on instead.

steps.title: One timer
steps.content: One timer When a player shoots the puck directly off the pass, timing his swing to redirect the puck as it comes towards them rather than stopping it first.

steps.title: Phantom assist/ghost assist
steps.content: Phantom assist/ghost assist When a player is credited with an assist that they didn't earn. Usually, they weren't even on the ice.

steps.title: Pizza
steps.content: Pizza A sloppy pass down open ice that an opposing player easily intercepts.

steps.title: Ride the pine
steps.content: Ride the pine A player who doesn't see a lot of action is said to be riding the pine .

steps.title: Sauce
steps.content: Sauce A pass that flies parallel to and over the ice, usually over an opponent's stick.

steps.title: Snipe
steps.content: Snipe A shot that flies straight past the goalie to score a goal, usually without the goalie even touching it or attempting to save it.

steps.title: Stoned
steps.content: Stoned When a player makes a great shot and the goalie saves it, you might say that the goalie stoned the shot.

steps.title: Take a look
steps.content: Take a look Players use this phrase to let a teammate with the puck know that there aren't any opposing team members nearby and they should look for a chance to make a play.

steps.title: Tape to tape
steps.content: Tape to tape A pass that goes easily from one player's stick to another player's stick with no intervention. Related: If there are multiple tape-to-tape passes in a row, you might refer to it as tic-tac-toe , as in, "Beautiful pass! There's a lot of tic-tac-toe going on out there."

steps.title: Traffic
steps.content: Traffic A situation where there are a lot of players in front of the net.

steps.title: Track meet
steps.content: Track meet A game where players race up and down the ice at top speed repeatedly because the puck changes hands so frequently.

steps.title: Warm up the bus
steps.content: Warm up the bus When one team is significantly ahead of the other and the outcome of the game is virtually decided, fans will chant to warm up the bus for the trip home.

steps.title: Wheel it
steps.content: Wheel it Players use this phrase to tell a teammate to skate with the puck, rather than trying to pass it.

steps.title: Bar-down
steps.content: Bar-down A shot that ricochets down off the crossbar and into the net with a loud clang that reverberates throughout the arena.

steps.title: Beaut
steps.content: Beaut A shot that's perfectly placed, timed, and executed to score a goal.

steps.title: Bottle rocket
steps.content: Bottle rocket A shot that knocks off the goalie's water bottle (which is usually sitting on top of the net).

steps.title: Celly
steps.content: Celly Celebration after scoring a goal

steps.title: Clapper
steps.content: Clapper A loud and decisive slap shot

steps.title: Dinger
steps.content: Dinger A shot that goes off the post, making a loud ding that reverberates throughout the arena.

steps.title: Egg
steps.content: Egg A game that ends tied at 0-0

steps.title: For the boys/for the girls
steps.content: For the boys/for the girls When a player says that they scored a goal not for their own glory but for their teammates.

steps.title: Five hole
steps.content: Five hole A shot between the goalie's legs that scores a goal. Related: A player aiming for the 5-hole could say that they were trying to tuck it in . Context: Goalies often defend from the butterfly stance, where they put their knees together and their feet out. This creates 4 possible zones for players to score. The zone between their feet when they're in this stance is the five hole . [11] X Research source

steps.title: Garbage goal
steps.content: Garbage goal A goal scored after the puck ricocheted out of the goal. The act of scoring a garbage goal can also be referred to as picking up the trash .

steps.title: Getting lit up
steps.content: Getting lit up A goalie who lets in a lot of goals is getting lit up . It refers to the light on the top of the goal that lights up whenever a goal is scored. Related: The player who scores a goal is lighting the lamp . You might also say a goalie who gets lit up a lot is sunburned .

steps.title: Gino
steps.content: Gino A goal

steps.title: Gordie Howe hat trick
steps.content: Gordie Howe hat trick When a player scores a goal, gets an assist, and gets into a fight in the same game. Context: The achievement is named after hall-of-famer Gordie Howe , a remarkable hockey player who spent 32 years playing for the NHL. And yet, he wasn't the first player to do this (he only managed the feat twice in his career). [12] X Research source

steps.title: Hatty
steps.content: Hatty A hat trick, when a single player scores 3 goals in a game. You can also have a natural hat trick , where that player scores those 3 goals consecutively without any other goals in between. Context: Hockey is typically a really low-scoring game, so scoring 3 goals in one game is a big deal. The phrase hat trick was borrowed from cricket, where scoring 3 times in a row is also very rare. When a player scores a hat trick, fans throw their hats onto the ice. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Muffin
steps.content: Muffin A weak shot that glides across the ice, seemingly in slow motion. A muffin is usually easily batted away by the goalie, although occasionally they score.

steps.title: Screened shot
steps.content: Screened shot This happens when there are players between the goalie and the shooter that are blocking the goalie's view of the shooter.

steps.title: Sieve
steps.content: Sieve A goalie who gets scored on a lot.

steps.title: Standing on their head
steps.content: Standing on their head If a goalie is getting hammered and they're making a save after humongous save, they're standing on their head .

steps.title: Swimming
steps.content: Swimming When a goalie is laying face down on the ice, flailing their arms and legs in an attempt to find the puck or make a save.

steps.title: Tendy or tender
steps.content: Tendy or tender The goalie or goalkeeper.

steps.title: Test the goalie
steps.content: Test the goalie Taking shots on goal regularly and consistently.

steps.title: Threading the needle
steps.content: Threading the needle When a player dangles multiple opposing players to make a shot on the goal.

steps.title: Windmill
steps.content: Windmill When a goalie makes a save while moving all of their arms and legs, kind of like a windmill.

steps.title: Wraparound
steps.content: Wraparound When you take the puck around the back of the goal from one side to the other and then score.

steps.title: Donnybrook
steps.content: Donnybrook Technically, a fight that involves more than 2 people. In practice, it's often a bench-clearing free-for-all. Context: The Donnybrook Fair, which was held in County Dublin until 1855, had a reputation for being the scene of much drunken brawling and carousing. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Face wash
steps.content: Face wash When one player puts the palm of their dirty, sweaty glove in another player's face and rubs it around a bit—usually after a check to try to stir up some trouble or start a fight. Context: Hockey players typically don't wash their gloves ever , so they can get pretty rank. This is not something you want in your face. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Sin bin
steps.content: Sin bin The box off the ice where players sit during their penalties; the penalty box

steps.title: Snarl
steps.content: Snarl The stage just before a fight, when players are facing off and probably trash-talking each other.

steps.title: Sucker-punched
steps.content: Sucker-punched When a player gets punched in the face by another player, typically when they have no means of defending themselves, such as when they're already down.

steps.title: Suey
steps.content: Suey Short for suicide pass , describes a situation where a pass results in the receiving player getting a hard check from an opposing player immediately.

steps.title: Tilly
steps.content: Tilly A fight, typically only involving 2 players.

steps.title: Turtle
steps.content: Turtle When a player curls up on the ice and covers themselves because someone is trying to start a fight with them and they don't want to fight.

steps.title: Yard sale
steps.content: Yard sale When a player is hit so hard that they lose all of their equipment, or when several players lose all of their equipment during a fight.
